questions.question: Where are you in your educational journey?

answers.answer: I'm currently in school for a health care related degree
I'm considering going back to school for a health care related degree
I'm considering going back to school for a degree that isn't related to health care
I'm not currently considering going back to school

questions.question: At work, a primary motivator for me is...

answers.answer: Helping others do their best at work. I like to develop plans and communicate them to a team.
Improving a person's quality of life and health. I like to help people.
Lifelong learning. I like to teach others and give them the tools to help themselves.
Making groundbreaking discoveries. I like to figure out how things work.
Finding insights in data. I like to develop and maintain systems and solve problems.

questions.question: I'd like to enhance health care through ...

answers.answer: Directing staff and planning finances.
Working directly with patients.
Educating new practitioners or community members.
Advancing the science of medicine.
Managing data and computer systems.
In a hospital or physician's office, but I'd be open to a residential care facility or government agency.
In a physician's office, hospital, or outpatient care center.
At a government agency or nonprofit, but I'd be open to working at a university or family services organization.
In a lab or at a university, but I'd be open to working in a hospital or office.
In an office or hospital, but I'd be open to working in a technical services or administrative support organization.
Leading and communicating with others. I have good attention to detail and enjoy analyzing information and using technology.
Empathetic communication and emotional stablility. I have strong problem-solving and interpersonal skills.
Breaking down big ideas so others can learn. I'm also good at analyzing information to inform big-picture problem solving.
Critical thinking, observation, and data analysis. I can also communicate complex ideas simply while speaking and writing.
Organization, project management, data analysis, and creative problem solving.
Accounting, administration, ethics, or economics.
Physical sciences or health care.
Education, public health, ethics, or a language.
Physical science such as biology or chemistry.
Biology, computer science, math, or management.
Some experience in an administrative or clinical role.
Some experience working in a lab setting or with patients as a medic, nurse, medical assistant, EMT, etc.
Some experience working in education or with a community organization.
I have some experience working in a lab setting or doing research, writing proposals, and writing about my findings.
I have some experience working with computers, databases, or information systems.

results.title: Executive
results.description: You have a natural ability to lead and make decisions. You thrive in high-pressure environments and enjoy taking charge of projects and people.
results.detailedDescription: You're an organized go-getter who's interested in the business side of health care. The idea of planning, directing, and coordinating medical and health services intrigues you. Adapting to an ever-changing landscape of health care laws, regulations, and technology doesn't phase you. You may already have a background in business or health care and find yourself ready for the responsibilities of management.

tabs.title: Motivation
tabs.content: The Executive may like to develop plans and communicate them to a team. They enjoy helping others do their best at work.

tabs.title: Skills
tabs.content: This role is skilled at leading and communicating with others. They have good attention to detail and enjoy analyzing information and using technology.

tabs.title: Works With
tabs.content: Careers in The Executive's path often involve working with health care providers and managing staff or finances.

tabs.title: Courses
tabs.content: The Executive may have taken college courses in accounting, administration, ethics, or economics.

tabs.title: Setting
tabs.content: A hospital or physician's office are common workplaces for The Executive, although they may also work in a residential care facility or government agency.

tabs.title: Education
tabs.content: Many jobs in this field require college courses in things like accounting, administration, ethics, or economics. Some roles require a bachelor's or master's degree.

tabs.title: Experience
tabs.content: People with experience in an administrative or clinical role tend to be a good fit for this The Executive's career path.

stats.title: Growth
stats.description: In employment of medical and health services managers over the next decade

stats.title: Median Salary
stats.description: For medical and health services managers, ranging from $83K to $119K averages

stats.title: Job Openings
stats.description: Predicted annually over the next decade due to workers retiring or transferring careers

degreeTabs.title: Master's
degreeTabs.content:
If you do have a bachelor’s degree and some work experience, an MBA in Healthcare Management is a smart next step. This MBA concentration will use a health care lens to give you a broad overview of business ethics, law, leadership, accounting, marketing, budgeting, and planning.

Colleges and universities have different names for their programs, so your preferred institution might call the degree by a different name—just look for a description that includes both health care and business.

degreeTabs.title: Bachelor's
degreeTabs.content:
If you don’t already have a bachelor’s degree, many universities offer a Bachelor’s in Health Administration. You can often earn these degrees online in an accelerated format.

Colleges and universities have different names for their programs, so your preferred institution might call the degree by a different name—just look for a description that includes both health care and business.

results.title: Practitioner
results.description: You enjoy working directly with people to help them solve problems and improve their lives. You have a hands-on approach and prefer to be in the field rather than behind a desk.
results.detailedDescription: You’re an empathetic person who likes to help others. Things like anatomy and biology intrigue you, and natural bodily functions don’t phase you. Whether it’s through nursing or surgery, therapy or routine care appointments, what matters to you is improving the health of others. You may already have a background in patient care and are ready to advance your career, or you may be answering a new calling.

tabs.title: Motivation
tabs.content: The Practitioner likes to help people. They enjoy improving a person’s health or quality of life.

tabs.title: Skills
tabs.content: This role is skilled in empathetic communication and tends to be emotionally stable. They have strong problem-solving and interpersonal skills.

tabs.title: Works With
tabs.content: Careers in The Practitioner’s path work with patients and other medical professionals. They may be interested in all patients or those with a specific need.

tabs.title: Setting
tabs.content: A physician’s office, hospital, or outpatient care center are common workplaces for The Practitioner.

tabs.title: Education
tabs.content: Jobs in this field often require college courses in physical sciences or health care. Many roles require a bachelor’s, masters, or professional degree.

tabs.title: Experience
tabs.content: People with experience working in a lab setting or with patients as a nurse, medical assistant, EMT tend to be a good fit for The Practitioner’s career path.

stats.title: Growth
stats.description: In employment of healthcare occupations over the next decade

stats.title: Median Salary
stats.description: For healthcare practitioners and technical occupations, ranging from $30K to $163K averages

stats.title: Job Openings
stats.description: Predicted annually over the next decade due to workers retiring or transferring careers

degreeTabs.title: Master's
degreeTabs.content:
If you have a bachelor’s degree and want to further specialize your studies, these are some popular master’s in the health field:
  • Master of Science in Nursing (MSN): This program expands your nursing skill set and prepares you for roles such as nurse administrator, nurse educator, clinical nurse specialist, and more
  • Master of Physician Assistant Studies: This program can prepare you to become a certified physician assistant, health educator, medical services manager, and more
  • Master of Occupational Therapy (MOT): This is often the minimum credential required to practice occupational therapy, while many go on to earn the Doctor of Occupational Therapy

degreeTabs.title: Professional
degreeTabs.content:
To reach the pinnacle of patient care, you can earn a professional doctorate such as:
  • Doctor of Nursing Practice (DNP)
  • Medical Doctor (MD)
  • Doctor of Dental Surgery (DDS)
  • Doctor of Dental Medicine (DMD)
  • Doctor of Osteopathic Medicine (DO)
  • Doctor of Pharmacy (PharmD)

degreeTabs.title: Bachelor's
degreeTabs.content:
If you don’t already have a bachelor’s degree, there are many good options to pursue based on your career of interest. Some popular ones include:
  • Bachelor of Science in Nursing (BSN): This program may allow for specialization into specific areas of nursing and often qualifies students to pursue nursing licensure in their state
  • Bachelor’s in Biology: This is a popular undergraduate degree for students who will go on to pursue a master’s or professional doctorate.
  • Bachelor’s in Nutrition and Dietetics: This degree can prepare you to work in roles such as health and wellness, K-12 nutrition programming, nutrition education, food labeling, and more. If you become a Registered Dietitian Nutritionist, there are even more roles available.

results.title: Educator
results.description: You have a passion for teaching and sharing knowledge with others. You are patient, empathetic, and have a talent for explaining complex ideas in simple terms.
results.detailedDescription: You’re a lifelong learner who likes to help others better understand a subject you’re passionate about. You may have a deep specialized knowledge in a health field you’re eager to share with future medical professionals—or you may want to educate entire communities on public health topics. You may have a background in patient care or education and want to share your talents to make a lasting difference.

tabs.title: Motivation
tabs.content: The Educator likes to teach others and give them the tools to help themselves.

tabs.title: Skills
tabs.content: This role is skilled at breaking down big ideas so others can learn. They’re good at analyzing information to inform big-picture problem solving.

tabs.title: Works With
tabs.content: Careers in The Educator’s path often work with community residents, aspiring health care professionals, or people with disabilities.

tabs.title: Setting
tabs.content: A government agency, nonprofit,  university or family services organization are common workplaces for The Educator.

tabs.title: Education
tabs.content: Jobs in this field often require college courses in things like education, public health, ethics, or a language. Roles require a bachelor’s or master’s degree.

tabs.title: Experience
tabs.content: People with experience working in education, health care, or with a community organization tend to be a good fit for The Educator’s career path.

stats.title: Growth
stats.description: In employment of health education specialists and community health workers over the next decade

stats.title: Median Salary
stats.description: For health education specialists, $46K for community health workers, and $102K for medical educators

stats.title: Job Openings
stats.description: Predicted annually over the next decade due to workers retiring or transferring careers

degreeTabs.title: Master's
degreeTabs.content:
If you do have a bachelor’s degree and want to further specialize your studies, these are some popular master’s in the health education field:

  • Master’s in Health Education and Promotion: This can prepare you for leadership positions in academic, clinical, community, or corporate settings, such as a community health coordinator or wellness coach.
  • Master of Public Health (MPH): The MPH is professional degree that gives you tools to impact public health in careers such as a public health educator, clinical research coordinator, epidemiologist, or health policy analyst.
  • Master of Science in Public Health: This is more of an academic research degree that will prepare you for doctoral studies.
  • Master of Medical Sciences in Medical Education: This type of program teaches things like the science of learning, curriculum development, and adult learning theories as well as training on current tools and research relevant to the field you’d be teaching.

Colleges and universities have different names for their programs, so your preferred institution might call the degree by a different name—just look for a description that includes both health care and education.

degreeTabs.title: Doctoral
degreeTabs.content:
If you’re interested in teaching future medical professionals, a PhD in Health Professions Education (HPEd program and prepare clinicians and other health professionals without a research degree to make contributions to the scholarship of teaching and learning.

A Doctor of Education (EdD) in Health Education could also be a good fit for those interested leadership roles related to advocacy and policy development, administrative leadership in organizations providing appropriate care to communities, and university roles that train the next generation of health education specialists, community health educators, and public health professionals.

degreeTabs.title: Bachelor's
degreeTabs.content:
If you don’t already have a bachelor’s degree, many universities offer a Bachelor’s in Health Education or Health Promotion. You can often earn these degrees online. Employers may also accept bachelor’s degrees in business, social science, or other health care related fields.

Colleges and universities have different names for their programs, so your preferred institution might call the degree by a different name—just look for a description that includes both health care and education.

results.title: Scientist
results.description: You are naturally curious and enjoy solving complex problems. You are methodical, analytical, and enjoy using data and research to drive your decisions.
results.detailedDescription: You’re an intensely curious person with a drive to learn how things work or make groundbreaking discoveries. You may enjoy reading a patient’s lab results to find things a physician can help them improve—or you may be driven to cure a disease or find a treatment that will change many lives. You probably have a background in science but may also be a skilled writer.

tabs.title: Motivation
tabs.content: The Scientist likes to figure out how things work and wants to make groundbreaking discoveries.

tabs.title: Skills
tabs.content: This role is skilled at critical thinking, observation, and data analysis. They can also communicate complex ideas simply while speaking and writing.

tabs.title: Works With
tabs.content: Careers in The Scientist’s path usually work with other scientists or medical professionals.

tabs.title: Setting
tabs.content: A lab or university are the most common workplaces for The Scientist, but they may also work in a hospital or office.

tabs.title: Education
tabs.content: Jobs in this field often require at least a bachelor’s degree in a physical science, and many prefer a Ph.D. or medical degree.

tabs.title: Experience
tabs.content: People with experience working in a lab setting or doing research and writing proposals tend to be a good fit for The Scientist’s career path.

stats.title: Growth
stats.description: In employment of medical scientists over the next decade

stats.title: Median Salary
stats.description: For medical scientists, ranging from $50K to $166K averages

stats.title: Job Openings
stats.description: Predicted annually over the next decade due to workers retiring or transferring careers

degreeTabs.title: Doctoral
degreeTabs.content:
PhD programs for medical scientists typically focus on research in a particular field, such as immunology, neurology, or cancer. Popular PhD options include:

  • PhD in Biology: This degree can prepare you for research in fields such as microbiology, environmental science, pharmaceutical development, genetics and more
  • PhD in Chemistry: This degree can prepare you for research in fields such as pharmacology, biomedicine, toxicology, and more.

Medical scientists also may pursue these medical degrees:

  • Medical Doctor (MD)
  • Doctor of Dental Surgery (DDS)
  • Doctor of Dental Medicine (DMD)
  • Doctor of Osteopathic Medicine (DO)
  • Doctor of Pharmacy (PharmD)
  • Doctor of Nursing Practice (DNP)

degreeTabs.title: Master's
degreeTabs.content:
A good master’s degree for those pursuing a medical science career is a Master of Science in Medical Science. It’s goal is to help medical students prepare to become competent physicians, but it can also prepare you for a more research-focused career.

Another option is the Master of Science in Clinical Research, which focuses more on quantitative and analytic skills in patient-oriented and translational research, as well as more traditional clinical investigation.

degreeTabs.title: Bachelor's
degreeTabs.content:
If you’re just getting started down the path of The Scientist, it’s a good idea to earn your Bachelor of Science in Biology or Chemistry. This will give you a strong foundation for future degrees.

Another options is a Bachelor of Science in Health Sciences, which can give you a strong skill base for clinical research. You’ll get an learn how to conduct research studies to ensure the safety and effectiveness of new drugs, devices, diagnostics and treatment regimens.

results.title: Analyst
results.description: You enjoy working with numbers and data to identify patterns and solve problems. You have a keen eye for detail and are able to see the big picture while also paying attention to the small details.
results.detailedDescription: You’re a person who likes connecting the dots. You think in systems and see patterns where others might not. You probably enjoy working with computers and a complex spreadsheet doesn’t phase you. You may already have a background in analytics or information systems and are interested in transferring those skills to health care—or you may be in an administrative role looking to upskill.

tabs.title: Motivation
tabs.content: The Analyst likes to develop and maintain systems and solve problems. They often enjoy solving puzzles presented by data.

tabs.title: Skills
tabs.content: This role is skilled at organization, project management, data analysis, and creative problem solving.

tabs.title: Works With
tabs.content: Careers in The Analyst’s path tend to work with medical professionals and computer systems.

tabs.title: Setting
tabs.content: An office or hospital are common workplaces for The Analyst, but they may also work for a technical services or administrative support organization.

tabs.title: Education
tabs.content: Jobs in this field often require college courses in things like biology, computer science, math, and management. Some roles require a bachelor’s or master’s degree.

tabs.title: Experience
tabs.content: People with experience working with computers, databases, or information systems tend to be a good fit for The Analyst’s career path.

stats.title: Growth
stats.description: In employment of health information technologists and medical registrars over the next decade

stats.title: Median Salary
stats.description: For health information technologists and medical registrars, ranging from $30K to $98K averages

stats.title: Job Openings
stats.description: Predicted annually over the next decade due to workers retiring or transferring careers

degreeTabs.title: Master's
degreeTabs.content:
If you do have a bachelor’s degree and want to further specialize your studies, these are some popular master’s in the health information field:

  • Master’s in Health Informatics: This degree can prepare you to analyze data and improve data systems with the goal of improving public health systems, healthcare delivery systems, and patient outcomes.
  • Master’s in Bioinformatics: This degree provides skills in both biotechnology and computer science which opens doors in a wide range of analysis-driven careers.
  • Master’s in Health Care Analytics: This degree focuses more on the data side, helping you comply with key legal, regulatory, and ethical constraints around sensitive client data and practices advanced analysis and reporting techniques.

Colleges and universities have different names for their programs, so your preferred institution might call the degree by a different name—just look for a description that includes both health care and informatics or analytics.

degreeTabs.title: Bachelor's
degreeTabs.content:
If you don’t already have a bachelor’s degree, many universities offer a Bachelor’s in Health Information Management. You can often earn these degrees online.

Colleges and universities have different names for their programs, so your preferred institution might call the degree by a different name—just look for a description that includes both health care and informatics or analytics.

schools.title: University of North Texas
schools.subTitle: Health Sciences Center
schools.description: Located in Fort Worth, Texas, UNT’s Health Sciences Center is one of the nation’s premier academic medical centers. Its five schools specialize in Osteopathic Medicine, Biomedical Sciences, Public Health, Pharmacy, and Health Professions. No matter the area, HSC programs promote patient-centered education, research and compassionate health care.
schools.linkText: Learn About Health Sciences at UNT

schools.title: Fairleigh Dickinson
schools.description: With two New Jersey campuses and a wide range of online offerings, Fairleigh Dickinson offers flexible ways to earn your health sciences degree. Programs range from bachelor’s to master’s and professional doctorates, and there are a number of combined programs that streamline the process of earning both your undergrad and advanced degrees.

schools.title: San Diego State University
schools.subTitle: College of Health and Human Services
schools.description: Located in San Diego, California, SDSU offers a variety of health care certificates and bachelor’s, master’s, and doctoral/professional degrees. Programs in SDSU’s College of Health and Human Services provide students with a balanced and meaningful education, both inside and outside the classroom, to develop them into confident and compassionate professionals.
schools.linkText: Learn About Health and Human Services at SDSU

schools.title: University of Saint Francis
schools.description: Located in Fort Wayne, Indiana, the University of Saint Francis offers certificates, associate’s, bachelor’s and master’s degrees in health care. One-on-one faculty advising and a focus on real-world learning set USF’s programs apart. Plus, programs are developed with a Franciscan lens, which recognizes the dignity of each person and encourages serving others and society as a whole.
